title: HD 39901
text:
HD 39901(HR 2069) is an <a href="orange%20giant">orange giant</a> in the constellation of <a href="Columba%20%28constellation%29">Columba</a>. With an <a href="apparent%20magnitude">apparent magnitude</a> of 6.561, it is only visible when there is almost no <a href="light%20pollution">light pollution</a>. This star is currently located 646 <a href="Light-year">light-years</a> away from the <a href="Solar%20System">Solar System</a>, but is drifting closer with a <a href="radial%20velocity">radial velocity</a> of -9.54 km/s. If it were placed exactly 10 <a href="Parsec">parsecs</a> (32 light years), it would be at an apparent magnitude of -0.03.
Properties.
HD 39901 has a <a href="stellar%20classification">stellar classification</a> of "K3III", which means it's a K-type star that has exhausted <a href="hydrogen">hydrogen</a> at its core. It has only 1.25 times the <a href="Solar%20mass">mass</a> of the <a href="Sun">Sun</a> but has expanded to almost 21 times the latter's <a href="Solar%20radius">girth</a>. It radiates at 142.6 <a href="Solar%20luminosity">solar luminosities</a>, and has an <a href="effective%20temperature">effective temperature</a> of 4,374 <a href="Kelvin">K</a>, which gives it an orange-hue. HD 33901 has a weaker <a href="surface%20gravity">surface gravity</a> compared to other stars, and has a similar <a href="metallicity">metallicity</a> to the Sun, but is slightly enriched in heavy elements.
